dt: {bc}to remove from a surface with or as if with a broom or brush

dt.t: {it}swept{/it} the crumbs from the table
everything she cherished, might be {it}swept{/it} away overnight

dt: {bc}to remove or take with a single continuous forceful action

dt.t: {it}swept{/it} the books off the desk
the problem can't be {it}swept{/it} under the rug

dt: {bc}to drive or carry along with irresistible force

dt.t: a wave of protest that {it}swept{/it} the opposition into office

dt: {bc}to clean with or as if with a broom or brush
{bc}to clear by repeated and forcible action
{bc}to move across or along swiftly, violently, or overwhelmingly

dt.t: fire {it}swept{/it} the business district

dt: {bc}to win an overwhelming victory in or on

dt.t: {wi}sweep{/wi} the elections

dt: {bc}to win all the games or contests of

dt.t: {wi}sweep{/wi} a double-header
{wi}sweep{/wi} a series

dt: {bc}to touch in passing with a swift continuous movement
{bc}to trace or describe the locus or extent of (something, such as a line, circle, or angle)

dt.t: his eyes {it}swept{/it} the horizon

dt: {bc}to clean a surface with or as if with a broom

dt.t: the wind {it}swept{/it} through the treetops
proudly {it}swept{/it} into the room

dt: {bc}to move or extend in a wide curve or range
{bc}to gain immediate and unquestioning support, approval, or acceptance by a person
{bc}to win all the bets on the table

et: Middle English {it}swepen{/it}; akin to Old English {it}swāpan{/it} to sweep, Old High German {it}sweifen{/it} to wander
shortdef: to remove from a surface with or as if with a broom or brush
to destroy completely : wipe out —usually used with away
to remove or take with a single continuous forceful action

dt: {bc}toward or into a part of the ocean that is far away from land

dt.t: The boat headed {it}out to sea{/it}.
He fell overboard and was {phrase}swept out to sea{/phrase}.

shortdef: toward or into a part of the ocean that is far away from land

dt.t: He {it}swept aside{/it} questions about his son's arrest.
He {it}swept aside{/it} their objections, refusing to change his plans.

shortdef: to treat (something) as not important : to ignore (something)

dt.t: Floods {it}swept away{/it} several houses.
His performance today {it}swept away{/it} any doubts about his ability to play.

dt: {bc}to remove dust, dirt, etc., from (something) by using a broom or brush

dt.t: Please {it}sweep out{/it} the room when you're done working.

dt: {bc}to push, carry, or lift (someone or something) with great force

dt.t: The debris was {it}swept out{/it} to sea by the tide.

shortdef: to remove dust, dirt, etc., from (something) by using a broom or brush
to push, carry, or lift (someone or something) with great force

dt: {bc}to remove dust, dirt, etc., from (something) by using a broom or brush

dt.t: When I was {it}sweeping up{/it}, I found an earring that I had lost.
Can you please {it}sweep up{/it} the porch?

dt: {bc}to remove (something, such as dust, dirt, etc.) from a surface by using a broom or brush

dt.t: She {it}swept up{/it} the broken glass.

dt: {bc}to pick up (someone or something) in one quick, continuous motion

dt.t: She {it}swept{/it} the baby {it}up{/it} and carried her to the crib.

dt: {bc}to brush or pull (hair) away from the face

dt.t: Her hair {it}was swept up{/it} in a bun.

shortdef: to remove dust, dirt, etc., from (something) by using a broom or brush
to remove (something, such as dust, dirt, etc.) from a surface by using a broom or brush
to pick up (someone or something) in one quick, continuous motion
